title: Rochelle and Marvin Humes pose with Pudsey for star-studded Children In Need photoshoot
text:
Rochelle and Marvin Humes and Laura Whitmore brought out their playful sides as led the stars urging the public to get involved in this year's BBC Children In Need.

Embracing the theme of Get Together, Rochelle, 30, and Marvin, 34, posed up with beloved mascot Pudsey while Laura, 34, whipped her hair around while wearing heart shaped sunglasses.

Tess Daly, Fleur East, Danny Jones, Ashley Roberts and Rylan Clark-Neal are also asking people to come together and fundraise for disadvantaged children and young people throughout the UK.

Get involved! Rochelle and Marvin Humes (above) and Laura Whitmore brought out their playful sides as led the stars urging the public to get involved in this year's BBC Children In Need

Rochelle and Marvin looked delighted as they donned t-shirts emblazoned with empowering words while holding onto a cuddly Pudsey toy.

The couple have co-presented the show together since 2016.

Strictly Come Dancing host Tess, 50, said she was 'intensely proud' to be supporting the initiative again this year.

'In the last year alone, BBC Children In Need has been able to make a real difference to 600,000 young lives in communities the length and breadth of the UK - that's incredible, and it is all down to people up and down the UK coming together to help make a difference,' she said.

Smile: Presenter Laura, 34, whipped her hair around while wearing heart shaped sunglasses.

'I hope they do it again this year, because it really will change young lives.'

Former JLS star Marvin said: 'BBC Children In Need was one of my first experiences of charity. It was really powerful as a kid to find out that by simply doing things that I loved I could raise money which could go on to change someone else's childhood.

'I have seen first-hand how that £10 raised through a bake-sale, or £20 raised through a quiz, makes an impact, so whatever you decide to do, just have fun - I promise it will go on to do great things.'

Rylan added: 'Whether you want to do something exhilarating like jumping out of a plane, or something simpler like spending the day in your pyjamas with your work mates, I promise you the money you raise will go on to make a difference.

Cute: Tess donned Pudsey ears as she threw her support behind the good cause

'I personally recommend a doughnut bake-sale - I did that once at school and it was a very happy day!'

Children In Need's chief executive Simon Antrobus said: 'Every year we are amazed by the remarkable efforts of supporters going above and beyond to make an impact on the lives of children and young people across the UK.

'Bringing people together sits at the heart of BBC Children In Need and we hope that our incredible fundraisers have a great time getting together in 2019, knowing it will help us give children and young people the childhood they deserve.'

To date the British public has raised more than £1 billion for children and young people across the UK since 1980.

The 2019 appeal show will take place on November 15.
